content: JARPI (J.A.R.V.I.S AutoReply Protocol Initiative) is the name of a system I'm designing to automatically reply to low-quality, repetitive Bitcoin questions that the community is tired of regurgitating. This project is meant to demonstrate the positive impact that AI can have on Bitcointalk when it is used correctly.Posts are directly pasted into OpenAI's ChatGPT (manually), and the answer is screened manually, and then automatically copied and used to reply to a bitcointalk thread.It is powered by my shiny new toy, J.A.R.V.I.S. I found a way to defeat Cloudflare's captchas using Selenium and solving them manually, so this opens the door to a lot of interesting possibilities.Jarvis text will always be italicized (sorry, not underlined - that was a mistake) and in grey, and have the following disclaimer at the bottom:Code:This reply was auto-generated by [url=https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5449279.0]JARPI[/url], an AI protocol created by [url=https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?action=profile;u=2739424]NotATether[/url] for automatically replying to frequentlyasked questions.Some other useful things that JARPI can do (theoretically), including things that don't even utilize AI:- It can make a reply on newly created spamvertising topics alerting users that the content is spam and telling them to use the "Report to moderator" feature to remove the entire topic (because lets face it, we humans are being collectively outgunned in this area).- Similarly, for malware posts.- Ditto, for obvious scam attempts such as Bitcoin doubler, bitcoin mining exploit, and so on.- It can tell a user when a thread belong in the wrong board and prompt them to move it to the correct board, with a short instruction.- It can alert users when they are multi-posting (most likely 3+) and tell them to place all replies in one post, linking to the relevant Bitcointalk rule.- Depending on the plagiarism tools available, it can alert a user when a post risks being classified as plagiarism and tell them to provide a link to the source material - reducing the number of ban appeal threads of people who did not know this was a rule.Limitations:- JARPI cannot create new topics.- JARPI cannot quote-reply (yet).- J.A.R.V.I.S is a newbie account and thus currently has the same restrictions as other newbie accounts.- JARPI will not post on local boards, or on English boards where it makes no sense to ask a Bitcoin question there (e.g. News, Gambling, Marketplace > Goods).Roadmap:- Currently there is a single sample reply that is hardcoded in the script. Work is underway to allow any arbitrary reply to be passed. Done- Apply aforementioned BBcode and footer. Done- Prompt the operator for a thread ID to make the reply on.- Allow the operator to insert any quote using a quote ID that is in the BBcode.Examples of how JARPI can place high-quality answers on common questions:Quote from: cafter on April 14, 2023, 11:40:47 AMthere are many threads and news about people losing access to their wallets and forgetting or seed phrases,and it's better for scarcity of bitcoin,  but how can we know or speculate that the wallet is lost, and it is out of the supply? is there any platform where we can find lost wallets, if no, then it's a good idea to start a website and list every lost wallets.ChatGPT's reply:QuoteWhile it's true that there are many stories of people losing access to their cryptocurrency wallets and forgetting their recovery phrases or private keys, there is no way to know for sure if a particular wallet is lost or not. The nature of cryptocurrency means that wallets can be created and used anonymously, and it's impossible to track all wallets and their associated recovery phrases or private keys.There is no platform or website that lists lost wallets because the privacy and security of cryptocurrency users are paramount, and it would be unethical to share information about lost wallets without the owner's consent. Furthermore, lost wallets could be the result of malicious actors stealing private keys or recovery phrases, and it would be inappropriate to make that information public.If you have lost access to your own wallet and are unable to recover it, your best course of action is to contact the wallet provider's support team or seek assistance from a professional cryptocurrency recovery service. These services specialize in recovering lost cryptocurrency wallets and can help you regain access to your funds. However, it's important to note that these services can be expensive and may not always be successful in recovering lost wallets. It's always important to keep your recovery phrases and private keys safe and secure to avoid the risk of losing access to your wallet in the first place.JARPI reply (after manually cleaning up the AI-generated reply):QuoteWhile it's true that there are many stories of people losing access to their cryptocurrency wallets and forgetting their recovery phrases or private keys, there is no way to know for sure if a particular wallet is lost or not. The nature of cryptocurrency means that wallets can be created and used anonymously, and it's impossible to track all wallets and their associated recovery phrases or private keys.There is no platform or website that lists lost wallets because the privacy and security of cryptocurrency users are paramount, and it would be unethical to share information about lost wallets without the owner's consent. Furthermore, lost wallets could be the result of malicious actors stealing private keys or recovery phrases, and it would be inappropriate to make that information public.Furthermore, bitcoins can only be placed out of circulation if they are provably lost, such as being spent with an OP_RETURN script, or unclaimed coinbase rewards.Keep in mind that the basic idea is for the reply to be as correct as possible, so in this case, replies from other parts of the thread could also be put inside the blender, and irrelevant parts of ChatGPT answers are shaved off.Tips: Send them to bc1q4djl6pxt90nfs8fufdul26ufxukxxrczsfjj0h

I haven't seen any exact rule on AI written post but I think it will be forbidden when the unofficial rules of official bitcointalk forum will be re-written.Pure AI generated posts are likely to be lousy and factually incorrect. However, there should not be any problem with AI posts that are manually fact-checked by humans:Quote from: Poker Player on April 17, 2023, 07:03:28 AMQuote from: nutildah on April 17, 2023, 05:39:18 AMYes but TBH I kind of like it that way. I don't think the forum should be overhauled -- especially the design. The forum's primary purpose now is to act as a repository / archive for satoshi's posts, along with Hal and a handful of other early contributors / devs. As well as anything that could be regarded as "historically significant" in the timeline of bitcoin or cryptocurrency in general. It really doesn't matter if thick layers of spam get added on top so long as those early, formative posts are still visible an intact. And it would be weird to view satoshi posts in a new forum design that wasn't around when he was here.The original old, dusty, hole-punched books can be consulted thousands of years from now thanks to digitization. To preserve something you don't have to keep it in its original format.Besides I think they are two different things. I would leave the forum format as it is. However, for innovations such as IA, I am clear, if it were up to me all text that is a mixture of IA with human content and results in a quality post, welcome.(emphasis mine).Imagine if somebody asks a question such as the following:Quotehow to avoid telegram scams involving cryptocurrency?Normally such questions are havens for signature spammers who otherwise do not have anything useful to contribute to the discussion. However, AI (with a few redactions or additions in the content where necessary) can make a much superior answer:QuoteTelegram is a popular messaging app used by many in the cryptocurrency community, but it's also a platform that scammers use to deceive and defraud users. To avoid Telegram scams involving cryptocurrency, here are some tips to keep in mind:Verify the identity of the person or group you are communicating with. Scammers often impersonate well-known figures or organizations to gain your trust. Verify their identity through official websites or social media accounts.Don't trust giveaways or airdrops. Scammers often use the lure of free cryptocurrency to trick people into sending them money or personal information. Always be skeptical of offers that seem too good to be true.Be cautious of unsolicited messages. Scammers may send you messages offering investment opportunities or asking for personal information. If you don't know the sender, don't engage with them.Don't share your private keys or seed phrases. Your private keys and seed phrases are used to access your cryptocurrency wallet. Never share them with anyone, even if they claim to be a representative of a cryptocurrency project or exchange.Use a trusted cryptocurrency wallet. Make sure you're using a reputable and secure wallet to store your cryptocurrency. Research the wallet provider before using it.Do your own research. Always do your own research before investing in any cryptocurrency project. Don't rely solely on information provided by Telegram groups or individuals.Report suspicious activity. If you encounter suspicious activity on Telegram, report it to the platform's support team or to the appropriate authorities.The grey color combined with the italics enables it to stand out from the other shitposts. Although maybe, I will make it a darker shade of grey. It is also possible to fine-tune the answers from ChatGPT to precisely answer specific questions such as: "Is XYZ a scam <paste background information here>", "How to safely use metamask", "should I use a second phone number when buying bitcoin with an exchange", "How to avoid being a victim of SIM swap attacks" and so forth.I should note that JARPI is private software and as such, only I have the ability to make the posts.P.S. I haven't asked anyone about this yet, because I don't think anyone sees the potential for this yet (and partially because this is not bitcoin-dev mailing list where most proposals get instantly shut down or ghosted  ). Instead of wading through endless pages of posts looking for the answer to a question, you can immediately stop looking when you find a JARPI-created answer, and maybe even lock the thread at that point. In other words, JARPI reduces spam by preventing other people from paying attention to subsequent low-quality answers.

comments.body: Quote from: T3PR00T on April 18, 2023, 11:35:18 AMIt's not a forum related topic.I don't understand your comment?Anyway, time for a little experiment, related to one of the non-AI use cases of this robot.In Development and Technical discussion right now, we have two spam topics, which I will call topic number 1 and 2:Topic 1: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5449252.0Topic 2: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5449249.0In Topic 1, I have reported the thread for spam advertising. and in topic 2, I have used JARPI to request users to do the same. Both actions were taken around 11:30 UTC time.The goal of this experiment is to see which spam thread is deleted first. If topic 2 is deleted first, then that means this use case is effective, otherwise, that means it is not effective to use auto-generated replies to ask people to report posts, and I will halt that particular usecase.So now it is time to wait. No more using the bot during this time period.  EDIT: They were deleted in about 70 minutes at the same time. So I don't see any particularly amazing use case for spamvertising alerts. However, malware and phishing link alerts are still important. Let's try that next.
